stream_context.summary: Kaze works on an oil-themed boss fight (Oil Blargg) and related camera/attack behavior, while also hitting a major design philosophy issue: ROM hack players expect to be able to 100% everything, which restricts secret/optional challenge design. He explores a solution involving optional overworld-found “perks” that can make the game easier or harder without feeling like a traditional Easy Mode.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a clear design-philosophy revelation about completionism expectations in ROM hacks, plus a concrete potential system change (single selectable perk found in the overworld). Also includes a real dev pitfall (editing the wrong actor/code and reverting changes) and performance/animation FPS troubleshooting.

findings.summary: Kaze attempted an FPS/animation-speed improvement (related to a new version of code from “Silas/Celes”), but it caused Mario to appear locked to ~30 FPS; he reverted to an older GitHub version to restore expected behavior and planned to report back to the contributor.

While debugging the boss behavior, Kaze realized he had been editing the wrong entity/code (using the regular Oil Blargg instead of the Oil Blargg boss), explaining why earlier changes “weren’t working.”

Boss fight tuning: Kaze iterates on the Oil Blargg boss’s movement/attack behavior (rotation speed, forward velocity, attack startup) to keep dodging difficult but not unfair, explicitly noting when something feels “too difficult” for normal players.

Camera design for the Oil Blargg arena: he adjusts camera pitch/position to keep both platforms and the boss readable, experiments with moving/scaling the boss for visibility (eyes as a key readability feature), and adds a distance-to-boss adjustment so the camera can tilt up more when the boss gets close.
Hazard design decision in progress: Kaze asks what the penalty should be for falling into the oil, leaning away from instant death and toward something like damage-over-time to avoid frustration.

Audio/ROM constraint noted: an “unused song” idea was discussed but the current asset is a WAV that would consume ~5 MB of ROM; Kaze notes it would need to be converted to MIDI to be feasible on ROM size constraints.

Major design revelation: players approach ROM hacks with an expectation they should be able to 100% them, unlike many mainstream games where completion is not expected. Kaze argues this expectation closes off design space for hard-to-find secrets and optional hard challenges because players complain when they can’t fully complete the game.
findings.quote: We can’t put hard challenges without people complaining. We can’t put super secret hidden stuff without people complaining. And I think that really takes away a lot of design space.

findings.summary: Kaze articulates a guiding principle for handling feedback: he tries to respect player feelings even when he thinks the reasoning behind them is flawed, and views it as a design responsibility to counteract negative feelings tied to completion expectations.
findings.quote: My philosophy is, what people feel, in a way, is real. You can’t change that fact. But their reasoning is most of the time stupid. You should just ignore people’s reasoning. But you can never really ignore people’s feeling.

findings.summary: Potential systemic solution explored: instead of an explicit Easy Mode or an RPG-like badge menu, Kaze considers optional, overworld-discoverable “perks” where you can equip only one at a time (e.g., no void-out, higher spin jump, move-speed change). This reframes difficulty as player choice (reducing blame on the game) and makes the overworld deeper.
findings.quote: If anything, it’s gonna be a single perk that you can pick. And you will only get one perk at a time. I don’t want you to build a custom character.

findings.summary: Overworld philosophy: Kaze states the overworld must be “massive,” “intricate,” and “full of secrets,” calling it a make-or-break element for the game’s success—suggesting significant upcoming focus on overworld exploration design rather than treating it as a simple hub.
findings.quote: The overworld needs to be full of secrets. That is so important. That’s gonna make or break the game. Guaranteed.

findings.summary: Kaze reiterates a broader RTYI design goal: avoid mechanics that make players feel they should leave a level and return later with different preparation. He cites removing 100-coin stars as aligned with that goal and contrasts it with Yoshi coins, which save individually (reducing “leave and come back” pressure).
findings.quote: I don’t want the player to be in a level and then feel like, oh, I should leave this level and come back with a different set of equipment.

findings.summary: Schedule/context: Kaze ends early for a wedding and mentions he’s currently constrained by work on a separate “banjo hack,” hoping to return to streaming twice a week (Sat/Sun) once that is finished.

biobak.summary: Biobak pitches a narrative framing for an “unused song”/dojo area: after collecting items, a “grand trial” begins—Kaze likes the idea for introducing a final challenge, though notes the dojo may change and the current WAV asset is too large.
Biobak suggests adding “metal teeth” details to the boss visual design; Kaze reacts positively and flags it as a cool idea.

zeina.summary: Zeina is present live and interacts throughout; she confirms she finished the “wedding cart”/gift crafting task while Kaze is streaming and they banter about embarrassing each other on stream, showing comfortable co-working dynamics during dev sessions.

key_stories.title: Completionism expectations restrict ROM-hack design space
key_stories.summary: Kaze realizes that ROM-hack players often expect to 100% the game, unlike many modern games where full completion is not culturally expected. He argues this expectation blocks him from adding deeply hidden secrets or very hard optional challenges because players interpret the inability to complete everything as a flaw and review the hack negatively.
key_stories.challenge: How to create satisfying secrets and optional high-skill content without triggering widespread backlash from completionist expectations in the ROM-hack community.
key_stories.process: Kaze compares ROM-hack expectations to mainstream titles and cites Mario 64 Land’s S-rank backlash as an example. He runs a live YouTube poll to test audience expectations and brainstorms systemic ways to reframe difficulty/optional content.
key_stories.outcome: He begins outlining a possible solution: optional, overworld-discoverable single “perks” (one equipped at a time) that let players tune difficulty and feel responsible for their chosen challenge level, while also making the overworld deeper and more secret-driven.
key_stories.key_quote: We don’t have that on ROM-hacks. We can’t put hard challenges without people complaining.

key_stories.title: Boss iteration derailed by editing the wrong code/object
key_stories.summary: During Oil Blargg boss development, Kaze struggles with behavior not changing as expected. He later discovers he was editing the standard Oil Blargg rather than the boss variant, making his earlier debugging misleading.
key_stories.challenge: Confusing, time-wasting debugging when changes appeared to have no effect in-game.
key_stories.process: He tests attack states, rotation/velocity, and camera behaviors, then checks the relevant actor and realizes the wrong source was modified.
key_stories.outcome: With the correct boss code targeted, he resumes balancing difficulty and camera readability with more reliable iteration.
key_stories.key_quote: I used the Oil Blargg instead of the Oil Blargg boss. No wonder it didn’t work.

open_questions.topic: Designing around the expectation of 100% completion in ROM hacks
open_questions.context: Kaze argues that players expect ROM hacks to be fully completable and complain when secrets or optional hard challenges block 100%, reducing design freedom. He floated a poll and began exploring system-level fixes.
questions: What did the YouTube poll results show exactly (percentages), and did they change his plans for secrets/optional content?
Does RTYI aim to support true 100% completion for most players, or will it include “post-completion” content meant for only highly skilled/committed players?
How will RTYI communicate optional content expectations in-game (UI, NPC hints, endgame messaging) to reduce the ‘I must do everything’ pressure?
Will there be multiple completion tiers (e.g., ‘credits complete’ vs ‘true completion’), and how will rewards differ?

open_questions.topic: Overworld ‘perk’ system design and thematic fit
open_questions.context: Kaze considers overworld-discoverable perks (only one active) that can make the game easier or harder, as an alternative to a badge menu or explicit Easy Mode.
questions: What specific perks are on the short list, and which are ‘easy’ vs ‘hard’ perks? (e.g., no void-out, higher spin jump, speed changes)
Where in the overworld would perks be found, and what kinds of puzzles/secrets gate them?
How will the game tutorialize perks so struggling players can find help early without turning the overworld into a required scavenger hunt?
How will Kaze ensure perks don’t create the disliked ‘leave and come back with different equipment’ mentality?
What’s the in-world fiction for perks in RTYI’s tone (Yoshi’s Island-inspired) so it doesn’t feel like RPG systems bolted onto Mario 64?

open_questions.topic: Oil Blargg boss arena: penalty for falling into oil
open_questions.context: Kaze is undecided on how punishing oil should be, preferring not to make it too frustrating; damage-over-time was suggested as a good middle ground.
questions: What final behavior did he choose for oil: damage-over-time, knockback, slow/stun, HP reset, or something else?
How does the oil hazard interact with the soap/vehicle mechanic used to damage the boss?
How will the game signal the hazard rules visually (animation, sfx, HUD) to keep deaths feeling fair?

open_questions.topic: Camera rules during the Oil Blargg fight
open_questions.context: Kaze adjusts camera pitch based on distance and worries about losing platform readability vs boss visibility (especially the eyes).
questions: What are the final camera rules (distance thresholds, pitch curve), and are they reused elsewhere for boss fights?
Did playtesting reveal motion sickness or disorientation with auto camera changes?
Will players be able to disable/override this camera behavior cleanly (and does disabling break readability)?

open_questions.topic: Dojo area and the ‘grand trial’ intro concept
open_questions.context: An “Asian/dojo” area is mentioned as possibly the only one of its kind; an unused song and a “grand trial” setup were discussed, but the dojo’s inclusion is uncertain and the song is currently a large WAV.
questions: Is the dojo still planned for RTYI, and if so, what role does it play (main path vs postgame challenge gate)?
What is the ‘grand trial’ mechanically (movement mastery gauntlet, boss rush, time trial, etc.)?
Who owns the unused song asset, and what is the plan to convert it to N64-friendly format (MIDI sequence/instruments) without blowing ROM size?
